Lady called Cherry Oh reached out to me on tell, asking if I'm looking for part time job and join their project.
The gave me a number +6581069982, Corrina He and got me to contact her for more into.
By grafting things in commerce platform called overtook, just to boost order numbers which need to complete 45 mission than they allow to withdraw back the funds with commission given to you.

I managed to withdraw the first round and I thought thinking it was safe, But at the and attempt, the top up amount grew, I could only withdraw upon completion of 45 missions; the product price is boasting up to $8000 and that time I had already transfer $ask.

It will then be frozen.

To freeze, the only way is to reduce the number of agents who do not complete the order you need to find a way to finish as soon as possible and hopefully you can withdraw your funds and get your commission back as soon as possible .When, I quickly went to NPC to lodge a report.

Buyer contracted me via Carousell on 6 Act expressing interest in 2 small items prices at S$10.
He provided me with an email address to contact him to arrange meet or post, but his account was suspended within the next few minutes.
His screams red flag but I still remained him as I thought there could be valid reasons why his account was suspended, besides the items were not expensive.

I even wrote to Carousell inquiring about user's account but they were unable to disclose any into due to their privacy policy and even cautioned me not to proceed with any going transactions with him.
Anyway buyer goes by the name of Anthony who was very polite and prompt in all his replies, even though he is based in USA and wants to send the items to someone in Malaysia (another red flag).
He sent me recipient's failing address and contact number and wanted to know cost of items and shipping fees, agreeing to pay either through PayPal or bank transfer.
All this while, I was thinking as long as I don't receive payment, I will not ship items out so there's nothing to lose.
After informing him that he has to pay me S$17 for the items plus overseas shipping, he decided to purchase more items amounting to over S$100 without a single enquiry (yet another red flag).
Total cost of additional items inch registered international mail amounted to S$130.60 and he proceeded to pay via bank transfer without hesitation.
I received a transfer confirmation email almost immediately (see attached screenshots) from "Citibank".
Upon looking at the email content, I knew straightaway it was a scar.
There are just too many stories and cases that highlight buyers as victims but sellers are at risk too, esp now that the scars are getting to be more sophisticated.
Rule #1: Deep your transactions within the official platform, ignore any requests to divert conversations off platform.
Rule #2: To not ship out your items until you are properly paid, no such thing as the bank holding your money.
These scatters are running some MLM company.
They seemed keen to help you make money, and they usually used women to lure you into a WhatsApp group chat where other 'people' are friendly and keen to make money together as well.
The job seemed too good to be true - just by clinking links.
I ignored my gut instincts and went ahead with taking out my money to do 'jobs'.
it all happened too fast.
please do not be like me.
be vigilant.
To not let them get away with it.

Things started excavating quickly, he will just suddenly and random drop you a random WhatsApp call, and try to guilt trip you that you are avoiding him.

i requested for a video call.
But he gave quite a number of ridiculous reasoning like he can't do video calls because of where he is.
But promise to call me on a certain day when he goes back to Baltimore.
Calmer will try to sweet talk you and make you believe in him.
Once he got to Ukraine for his contract, 2 weeks later, he will call or send you a text that his mud pump is faulty and he needed financial help.
I was sceptic at first, but the way they speak to you, is so believable that you will think is true.
And he sounded really desperate that all i wanted was to help, which I eventually did.

And reasons for him asking for more money became more ridiculous, like paying his supplier and his workers, or having no money to eat, and needing to take a private jet back to the USA, so he can pay everyone that he has asked to borrow money from.
When i suggested to him to take a commercial flight, another stupid reason came out again, and he will guilt trip you by saying you don't understand what he is going through.
His was the time when i started to suspect that i got slammed, and made a police report.
Please be careful when meeting people on dating apes such as tinder, limb etc.The scatters will always sweet talk you and say how in love they are with you when you have never met them in person.
They will always give excuses when you say you want to meet.

They will start introducing you to investment schemes such as lottery apes which they found loopholes and have been earning money from the pp which no one is aware.The usual tactic they use is to entice you with small wins first and let you enjoy the gains for a period.When they will start to brainwash you to put more money in so that the returns you get will be higher.
Next is tell you there is a once in a lifetime promotion.
The more money you put in, the more bonus money you will get in return.
He will take the lead first and show you that he has put in all his money in and left you to pump in the money to enjoy the promotion.

He will pressure you with deadline, if the money is not pumped in within certain time, all your existing money in the account will be lost.Please be more alert when someone start talking to you about investment or money when you have never met the person.
These scatters have well thought out plan in mind to use on their victims.
Editor's Note: Investors are reminded to do their own due diligence before investing.
Always do a "Ask.
Check.
Confirm" to find out more about a scheme to minimise the possibility of getting slammed.
More resource on how to look out for investment scars can be found here: http://www.moneysense.go.sg/articles/2018/10/how-to-spot-an-investment-scar

Editor's note: Moan scatters or unlicensed moneylenders will attempt to impersonate licensed moneylenders to cheat.

First telltale sign: Display pictures of matches are usually very attractive females/males.
However, such pictures are often refused.
To there are two things which are easy to spot.
1) Pictures are usually low quality and low in resolution and grain looking.
2) There is a function in Google which you can do "Google image search".
http://images.goose.com/ Users can screenshot the profile picture and unload using the link to do an image search.
Should the image be refused a couple of times, it will show up in the search with multiple results.

(In almost immediate sign that the account is a scar account) Second telltale sign : The had a phone number which was a nonmoral number (+852) 1) While this may not be a straightforward sign.. this should raise some alarm.

Editor's Note: Please note that unlicensed moneylenders or loan scatters can impersonate licensed moneylenders to cheat.
They could set up face webster, disuse the licensed moneylender's company's name and licence number to fool the public.
To prevent falling prey to such scars, do not respond to online advertisements promoting moneylending services.
Licensed moneylenders are not allowed to promote or advertise their services on social media such as Facebook, SMS, or Whatsapp or via Google advertisements.

ASSOC is a command that displays the program and/or functionality ASSOCiated with a specific file type.
His particular CLSID is frequently misrepresented by scatters as being a unique identified of the victim‚Äôs system and/or a license of for the Windows operating system.
In fact, a CLSID is an identified that is unique not to a particular of, but to a COM class object, which means that it will be the same on any Windows system where that object can be found.
In other words, there are many millions of Windows computers where running the ASSOC command will show exactly the same text somewhere in its display.
It does not represent a unique of string for either the of or for a specific installation of Windows.

I was approached by a lady from china who goes by the name "king in" on what.

The claims to be from a well-to-do family from being and has an "uncle" who is a financial expert.After a couple of text exchanges she introduced me to invest in a cryptocurrency known as "orb", trading on a cryptocurrency online platform known as "bftbit" (www.bftbit.com).
Bftbit turns out to be a face trading platform and orb is a non-extent cryptocurrency.

Once ponies are deposited into bftbit it goes directly to the scatters, although on bftbit it reflect as deposited into your bftbit account and no matter how you try to withdraw the ponies, the withdrawal status would remain as "processing".In the beginning i was very skeptically and refused to believe her.

But a moment of greed and "too smart for my own good" led me to foolishly believe in her and lost an irrecoverable sum of s$14,500.The modes operandi:1) she would first introduce that she had been into this orb investment for 3 years under the guidance of her financial expert uncle who guides her to invest at the relevant time on bftbit which most of the time would be profit-making as the uncle knows the market.2) she would ask you to invest in a small sum of us$500 first which would make profits after 2 rounds of investment on bftbit.
The would also provide step-by-step guidance [i.e.

buying of cryptocurrency on hubs (an authentic and well-known cryptocurrency exchange incorporated in singapore), transferring of currency from hubs to bftbit, making trades in orb on bftbit and withdrawal and transferring of a small sum of currency from bftbit to hubs (this withdrawal is to make one believe that bftbit is an authentic trading platform but in fact the withdrawal is done by the scatters)].

From there, she would entice you to invest in us$10,000 as her uncle predict that a big market trend is coming, thus earning more profit.3) she would then suggest to make a joint trade of us$20,000 which would require us$30,000 as security deposit.
In order to gain your trust, she would transfer us$40,000 into your bftbit account.

Once you transfer your us$10,000 into the account it is gone forever.4) at the time when you (and her) are jointly trading on the orb big market trend, the trading system would stop for unknown reason and when you refresh the trading system you would realise that the joint trade suffers an 80% loss.

From there, she would claim to be your fault and ask for refund of her us$40,000.5) a much serious concern is that in setting up your account with bftbit you need to furnish a copy of your uric which is at the scatters' disposal.

I was a victim of an internet love scar.
It was a tormenting experience for me and it took me a year to forgive but not to forget.

I study the characteristics of such scatters and all have similarities in their operandi modes.Level 1) befriend you with 'hi', 'hello' , earn your trust, get quick inter on your background like martial status, family, whether you are staying alone, occupation to gauge your incomeLevel 2) romancing starts with dear, honey, sweet, cutis, etc.
Often romantic pictures, even sentimental music as drops too !

!Level 3) money issues often begin with a luxury gift box with hidden money stuck in malasha, need to pay clearance taxes in us$, emergency medical/surgery expenses, machinery repairs, lost wallet ...
The mind game begins.Level 4) hound you desperately, pitiful pleads etc .
Angry phone calls to pressure...They work in a team with different roles as the 'lover', logistics, government officer, bank officer like a well scraped drama.
They can face everything - instagram profile, facebook, logistics webster, crytocurrency webster, documentation.By advice - don't believe.
Clock immediately and get out of social media for a while to calm your mind.
Of possible, screenshots, record conversations.
To to our friendly police station if harassed.
On't stay quiet and suffer in silence !
It's even better if you can identify the scar before it hurts you!

It 2.pm on 26 May 2020 Tuesday, I received an email to my personal email (Sunk older) with my full name in the subject title.
I opened it and read the entire email as it had all my details.
I was very shocked and almost believed it as my full name, mobile number, date of birth, and address were stated in the beginning of the email.
These details are all accurate/current.
Because I share the same last name as this 'barrier' as well as have some relatives in Malaysia, I first thought the email to be true.
However, the tsunami disaster in December 26, 2004 seemed like such a long time ago for any inheritance matter to occur.
I knew it was a scar when he said that "we would share the percentage on a mutually agreed-upon 60% for me and 40% to your kind self" which seemed like an unfair percentage.
I am worried because if this summer managed to get my personal information, other people/scatters out there may have gotten my information.
Thankfully, the NRIC field is left blank which meant that the summer may not have this piece of information which is the most crucial.
To money was lost except my personal information (which I did not give my consent in giving away this piece of information, the summer had it already).
I showed my daughter this scar email, she did some research and found someone who has reported this email as fraud several years ago and she later advised me to share my story on this page.
Calmer's email addresses: LCCHNG80@YAHOO.COM.SGCHONGLIMM@LIMCHONGCHUANASSOCIATE.COM

when i asked him to verify that he is from single, he would ask you to have pen and paper ready to take down the information, then he gave the following information : Same = Stewart john; staff id=stls1059; tell=1800809651; customer of number (long string of numbers and alphabet); after giving these information, he would assure that this is not a scar and that is why he is able to give so much information.

I was looking for a personal loan online.
I was unfortunately landed on a summer goose ad which misrepresent a licensed moneylender.
His summer tested me requesting for my uric, 15 the cf statements, latest payslips and not particulars.
I was slammed a total of $ask as their "processing fee".
The whole incident was very traumatising.
Scammers will misrepresent those licensed moneylender and usually will use numbers which cannot call through.

Please beware of scatters and just report and block if you receive any.Editor's Note: Please note that licensed moneylenders are not allowed to advertise their services online, via essaying apes or SMS.
They are registered with the Ministry of Saw's Registry of Moneylenders (see list here: http://from.law.go.sg/files/of List as at 1 May 2020.of).

Some scatters may claim to be staff working for licensed moneylenders so the safest way is to get in touch with the moneylender via the contact number published on the webster or to visit the physical office.

A lady losing as single staff called my family member claiming to be checking on the pretext that the infrastructure is managed by Singtel (broadband account is under my name), and that our broadband may have been compromised by hawkers.
they asked my family member to install teamviewer and log in using their account.The phone was passed to me and they started to ask about whether i did internet banking.

I do not usually pick up calls from unknown numbers but since i have been ordering things online, i figured there might be times where the deliveryman may need to call me.
I received a call today 11 may 2020 at 11.am.
The number +6567892006 looks quite left so i answered.
I had to say "hello" three times and then came a man on the line who spoke in a thick indian accent.
He claimed that he is from "Singtel" and said there was something wrong with my internet connection / broadband.
I was like "hut?
can you repeat?"
It took a few seconds for him to answer (the line seems baggy) and he answered like he was reading from a screen.
Sensing that this might be a scar, I replied, "if there is something wrong with my internet, i would call single myself.
K bye!"
I hung up the phone immediately.
The call was made by a local number hence i picked it up.
it was an indian lady with a thick accent.
she claimed that she was from single and that there were unauthorized devices that connected to my home wife.
i was a little panic but then i remembered that the household select was starhub.
I told her i was under starhub and she insisted on transferring the call over to starhub.
i then hung up.
A indian man IMPERSONATING SING-TEL called me on 11 may 2020 9.am to inform that my SING-TEL wife is compromised and there are UNAUTHORIZED access, so he requires some information from me.
I proceed to ask him for the exact time and date it OCCURRED, he told me from the time i went online.
I insisted on having the time and date of the UNAUTHORIZED access and he requested me to switch on my computer to do so.
I refused and repeatedly asked for more information regarding the UNAUTHORIZED access which FRUSTRATED him and he hung up.
I lost $4500 to Moan scar and there are other victims as well - http://www.scamalert.sg/stories-details/Story-15Apr2020103940AM .
I have already gone to the police and found out that the webster that I visited might not have belonged to the actual business owner.

Was then later asked to transfer more for a "lawyer fee" They go by several arises of jackson,james,victor,demand.
When confronted they claim they have been getting away with this for 20 years.

Would like to highlight the fact that this is my hard-earned money which they have slammed me of Please be wary and call up the licensed moneylenders found listed in this list http://from.law.go.sg/files/of%20List%was%that%201%20May%202020.of for more information.

Must sharing my personal experience on the people who i talked to on social networking sites.
By going through the stories posted by the victims in this site, i noticed there are some similar signs of warning which i experienced.
1. attractive photo - His is the first magnet that lured me into engaging a conversation with them.
i even did a reverse image search on the photo but it return zero results.
2. self-Proclaimed millionaire - Claimed that he owns a factory in sake, showing pictures that he is driving a porch.
In my two encounters, they are very wealthy in their early was.
3. where are they - interesting enough, they are never near to me.
they are either in guangzhou or in sake.
4. language preference - not being racism here, most of them are chinese.
they are more comfortable to converse in chinese.
but in my recent encounter, he is quite client in english.
5. touching stories - about how poor he was in the past and able to make a name for himself as the boss of a company.
for the other guy, he is a divorce, claimed that his wife created on him.
6. investment methods - seems like they very into crept currencies.
they claimed that they have uncle abroad who knows the market very well and posted screenshots of their earnings.
in my first encounter, he was very push to get me to buy some bitcoins and play some game in a chinese webster.
hope this helps.

I'm going to share on how the scar works.
I have tried this out of curiosity to experience what the victims are going through.
The Credit for Ex Scammers usually don't have a local number tied to their advertisement, instead they will use a Line-of or a WeChat-of.
The only way to connect with them is via these apes.
They can advertise their services on Locanto, or Hinder or any other possible webster.
The one I experienced was via Locanto, and was directed to add this person on WeChat.
Upon contracting the "masses" or the "escort", they will pretend it is a legitimate proposition by asking you when you would like to meet them.
Once you have given them a date and a time, they will ask for your location.
The location I was given was ‚Äú102 Shun Avenue 5‚Äù.
Upon arriving at the location, the girl will request for you to take a picture of your surroundings to indicate you have reached the meeting place.
Next, they will ask you for your contact number so that their ‚Äúfriend‚Äù can contact you with further instructions and direct you to their actual location.
Once you have given your contact number, their friend will call you via an Unknown or Private number, and ask you a series of questions.
The questions asked will be whether or not this is your first time with this girl and if you have any friends or family who are in the police force.
Once they have verified that this is your first time and that you do not have any connections to the police, this is when they will proceed with the scar.

He will then ask you to pay a deposit of $100 or $200 for the services which you requested via an AXS machine, selecting the Top Up ‚Äì Alipay option with their e-mail given to you by the girl via the essaying pp.
His is the first red flag!
Once you have done so, you will be requested by the girl to take a picture of the receipt and send via the pp.
Next, the ‚Äúfriend‚Äù will then ask you to make a ‚Äúrefundable deposit‚Äù of $1,200 as this is their company policy.
They will justify it by saying that the girl is a student and is doing this illegally, the money will be used to bail them out in the event they are caught and deported back.
To not transfer the money!
Second red flag!
Once you have rejected transferring the money, he will begin to threaten you by saying he have your contact number and will track you down and hurt your family.
They will then negotiate with you by asking you to make a smaller amount for deposit.
The girl will even call you on the essaying pp to plead with you that it is for your safety.
Stay calm!
His is all a scar.
Stop stopping up nor deposit any more money and report to the police.

I've seen this a lot of times recently, this is the third time a friend of mine was impersonate, all on instagram.
The first time, it was my boyfriend's mother (her instagram surname was xxxi, they changed it to caroline_teo???
), the next time it was a friend i haven't spoken to in ages (Mania??
to amandaa??)
and the third time, was a girl i hadn't spoken to in awhile as well (hoyeex to hhoyeex).
These are really common, and they often choose surnames that are really similar, and difficult to detect if they are false.
Of course, this is partially due to the accounts being public, thus letting them copy the pictures.
The first time they asked for my phone number (i gave it because i thought it really was my boyfriend's sum), and asked if i could give my bank account details and click an SMS link.
Thankfully, my account is a up number, and thus i did not receive it- i do not think the message could send.

I thus kept the conversation going to try and figure the identity of the summer, but all i managed to get was that he spelled singapore as sinapur, and was thus likely from india (their cities spell 'more' as 'our').

The second time they did not message me, and the third time, they asked for my phone number (i gave the police number), of which they said they sent an sums code to it, and asked me to send it to them to verify.
Is i 'played' with them to try and get more information since it was evidently a scar, they accidentally type some words in rumania, and delete it a few seconds later.
I tried to continue the conversation but they ignored me afterwards.
To money was lost in any of these three situations, but the cases really are on the rise, so i thought it'd be nice to perhaps inform and warn more people of such scars.
Thanks!

Calmer instructed me to use Huobi pp to exchange fiat currency to USDT.
After that using the USDT to deposit into Ruibtc trading site.
I did In internet trustworthiness check on both and came up with not much issues.
Huobi is valid and security seems good with a large amount of traders using it.

Ruibtc passed as well.
That only meant the CRYPTOCURRENCY was the problem.

By encouraging investors to buy in and push value up and once that happens the scatters in control of the CRYPTOCURRENCY would dump/sell all of their units making the later investors lose their investments.

All posts were recently made.

RECEIVED a call from a local handphone number .
It was a voice recording message in chinese.
"Your OCBC account is suspended due to SUSPICIOUS activity.
Please press '9' to continue.
It then moved on to a short sentence in English but repeated the Chinese recorded message again.
Received SCAM call from China DHL branch automatic service (phone number: 9993 1687), then connected to an actual Chinese speaking phone operator.
In Chinese the Operator told me that my phone number was associated with a parcel that contained 8 counterfeit passports, that was sent from Singapore to That Sang, Seizing.
They took down my Chinese name and my first name.
I told them I had nothing to do with this.
They told me that if I really had nothing to do with this, I should let the Seizing Seaport Security Authorities know directly.

In the meantime, they gave me the away number of the parcel CL69238080DE, the tender's address "Singapore 160056" as well as the intended recipient name and address: Or. Long When, #18 That Sang U, Men Ai A Lie, phone number: +86 13213065371.
It this point I was still not sure if it was a scar, so when he asked if he could connect me to the Chinese officials that deal with such parcels, I said ok.
He connected immediately to Officer King In.

He asked me why I was calling and explained that he was the Chinese Tea Sort authority dealing with sea freight packages and that my phone number was on a parcel that contain the counterfeit passports.
I said yes, DHL informed me and asked me to speak to you, how do I deal with this?

He said that this was a very serious issue and that according to Chinese law, I had to physically go to the office in That Sang Seizing to do a recorded interview / deposition, explaining that I had nothing to do with this parcel - this was the only way to clear my name.
I said that is 100% impossible, as I live in Singapore and that I was not going to fly anywhere to do this.
He said it's ok, we can schedule the deposition timing to Monday, 19 Dug 2019 at am and everything can be done on the phone.
I asked why they didn't want to have black and white email correspondence?
and Officer King In said that that is not how they do it in China.
Everything will be done over the phone with his superior next Monday and that recording will serve as evidence that I am not involved in this.
I said ok and then hung up.

I growled the away bill and it did not turn up on the DHL webster; I then growled for "SCAM CHINA DHL" and found out that more than 200 people had received this call as well, where DHL China tells them that their phone number is associated with a rogue parcel containing 8 counterfeit passports.
I then knew for sure that it was a scar, and I will not be taking the call on Monday.
Worried about the fact that they have my Chinese name and first name in English and also worried that others will face the same scar and give up personal information.
On't be fooled into releasing into over the phone!

I would like to take this opportunity to share my experience to everyone who intended to rent out their room or house, must be aware of this type of people.
Dear friends, I have to give buds to staff at Elements Most Office who refused to accept my request to relit money on someone's behalf.
Their due diligence have saved me from financial and emotion loss.
Were's the story ‚Ä¶ I have a room to let and advertised online.
A person named TMJ responded and expressed interest.
TMJ claimed she is Singaporean (even gave her NRIC front image) and returning from China to Singapore.
Her only condition was for me to open a Carpal account as it was her only mode to relit money.
I suggested other mode of payment but in vain.
Once I had opened a Carpal account, an email from service@papal.com.sg averted that I had funds coming in but had to wait 3-5 working days before actual fund is created.
The sum was more than what I had asked for because Tenant TMJ wanted me to help her pay her over's fee as she was away on business trip in India.
To pay her over, I was asked to relit fund through Western Union Bank.
I mentioned that I will act once funds are created into my account but Tenant said the over needs to be paid 'tomorrow'!!!
Cannot wait ‚Ä¶ With kind thoughts to help, I agreed.
Once I was at the Elements Most Office, the staff asked a very important question.
By answer raised suspicions and I was asked to head down to Western Union Bank, near J-cure.
Is I was driving towards J-cure, I sense something was not right.
Stopped my car and gave Carpal Singapore a call.
The answers were shocking!
Carpal confirmed there was no funds created into my account and no email was sent to me.
Carpal does not required 3-5 working days to credit any account.
Fund transfer is immediate !
That a narrow escape from email summer !

I was looking for a room to rent and i made contact with the "landlord" on easyroomate.com.
Things progressed quickly, with him asking me for personal information regarding the rental etc.
I was alright to provide it.
But strangely, i felt that he kept repeating himself in the messages because i had already answered the questions!
i felt that it was strange because it seemed like he didn't actually read my replies and was giving me canned responses.
despite me asking to view the room, he didn't arrange for one and said that the current tenant was away for christmas and her sum was sick so he didn't when she'll be back.
also, he said he didn't have a local bank account because it was undergoing 'linking' with his bank account in london.
i know that's rubbish because there's no need to 'link' bank accounts.
the most important details was how he kept pressing me for the rental deposit of 1000 and front 2 months rent.
i said i'm alright to pay for it and said that i need to set up a recurrent filling with my citibank account and i will need his bank account details and rental contract.
the rental contract came.
it seemed to be done up on ms word with poor margins and clipart and the watermark confidential all over it.
there is no attorney address or third party signature.
there is no mention of landlord's nationality, passport number/in number etc.
the address of the home is genetic and does not have a unit number.
there are lots of clauses which talk about late payment charges and trying to make it seem very official, however, the language use is quite poor if it were really written by a lawyer.
when i made objections, he wasn't happy to provide more details.
the bank account he gave me was an account in the of.
no local bank account, no local representative and there was an obvious rush for me to transfer the money to him and a lot pressure for me to provide a receipt.
the strangest thing is the name of the account holder.
the account is registered to a man called 'innocent alone'.
when i searched it up, there is no such person to have passed the bar in london.
i am glad that i asked all the right questions.
this guy wasn't able to answer them and i quickly realised that it was a scar.
please be aware of such scars as the pictures provided and the rental cost is very attractive.
people who have been looking for rooms for a long time will feel like its the perfect place for them and will rush to put a deposit down to secure it.

Were is Facebook ADVERTISEMENT, which will lure you to buy the product, advertisement will show the comparison, feature, video and all possible element to win your confidence.
they will table the offer at price point which is Fig trap (shall be first sign we shall be CONSCIOUS of).
Most important element, they will mention cash on delivery, hence we will feel least risk to get the product, but this is the trap and beware of this.
Unfortunately i ordered this product and i got the message for "Nina An" with secure code to share at the time of delivery.
you feel confident that delivery is secure - it is another trap you are getting into.
Finally Nina van will show up on your door and will hand over a sealed packed and demand cash.
they will caution you if you open the packet it is consider receipt of delivery hence you are obliged to pay money.
however if you do not open, you will establish the facts of fraud later.
i got wrapped and my wife (at home) paid the amount, however after opening the packet, i REALIZED that product is nowhere close what was advertised.
hence i called immediately nina van team and told them that the product is face.
There are many customers who have received the same packet and reached out to "Nina An team" to ensure their cash is not paid to seller and they shall be able to protect customer from this fraud.
but they flatly refused me & others and informed me that as soon as i signed the delivery slip they emitted the money to seller.
Hence, I asked them to share the details of seller name, account number and requested them to raise the matter and inform local AUTHORITIES.
there did not share any details nor shown any concern about the money lost by multiple customers, which made me believe they are either part of fraud or may be creator of fraud.
how can a company send instant payment to an unknown seller and that to INSTANTANEOUSLY, hard to digest this.
Were are the symptoms you must check: 1.
Great price deal - Check reputation of online seller 2.
These webster will not send you confirmation mail or will send you confirmation mail from alias with "not-to-reply" without any real contact details.

Check the delivery message you will get - here are steps which you help you establish the fraudulent intent - Click on the message tender - Unteachable number - as they masked the message sending details - if you respond to message it will bounce back I felt important to share so that i shall be able to help my fellow citizens to beware themselves against these scars.
Please share with your friends and relative to educate them and help them save their money.

The online platform was not a real trading platform, but you wouldn't know because they designed it professionally.
Their facebook page has many likes, all a set up because I am very sure that the likes are all set up by their own employees.
The broker use face names.
They use VOIP numbers and you will not be able to trace where they are calling from even though they use face call locations like London and Switzerland.
They try to gain your trust and make profit.
They will use complicated money making methods and may eventually swallow your money if you give them authority to manage your account.
After you deposit more money, they will ask you for more money.
They will ask you whether you want to test their system for withdrawal to gain your trust.
The realization dawned when I wanted to book all my profits and withdraw all my profits and principle amount and I am met with excuses upon excuses.
They will not give you back your money.
But managed to claim back much through a credit card chargeback.
Of I had teletransfer the money through a bank instead, all would have been lost.
After I stopped trading with them, they have been harassing me weekly with VOIP calls from their related scar brokerage and finance firms.
Lesson learnt.

Beware: 1) do not teletransfer to strangers 2) do not trade with broker not authorized by the government 3) do not trade with people you haven't met and does not have physical presence in your country

I am an investigation journalist and did a research on the Sugar Mummy scar circus in Singapore.
They all operate the same way.
To one is what they say they are.
I contracted 6 of the agents on Locanto and other sites via WhatsApp and they were all scatters.
They might change names but one thing is for 100% sure.
You will be slammed!
Basically they have a pre-paid phone card with a genetic profile photo.
They all sure you they are not scatters.
After giving them you name, age and civil status they will ask for 300-500 SGDs for a fee.
They only accept bank transfer.
When when you have played this they ask for 1400-1900 SGD for further fees and insurance.
They promise you a BMW and a monthly salary of at least 10500 SGD and so on.

On¬¥t fall for any sweet talk or promises, you will be fooled and no sugar mummy is at the end of the rainbow.
To matter who they say they are or that they have lots of clients that recommend them, nothing they say is true.
